episode_summary: This episode features discussions on human navigation and the tendency to walk in circles, Alexander Pope's self-criticism under a pseudonym, the pioneering brain mapping work of Wilder Penfield, and a Samoan king's plot involving a cricket team disguise.

facts.fact: People who get really lost usually don't travel more than a hundred meters from their starting point, regardless of how long they walk for.
One of the fiercest critics of poet Alexander Pope was a writer called Esdras Barnivilt. This was a secret identity, and the real person criticising Alexander Pope was Alexander Pope.
The first person to map the functions of the brain did so by literally sticking labels to different bits of it on a living person.
In 1885, a Samoan king plotted to kill a rival by disguising his army as a 200 man cricket team.
